statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Vermont 69, Boston U. 58
article.story: BURLINGTON, Vt. (AP) -- Seniors T.J. Sorrentine and Taylor Coppenrath each scored 16 points but it was a freshman, Josh Duell, who gave Vermont a big boost Sunday as the Catamounts topped Boston University, 69-58. Duell was a perfect five-for-five from three-point range for a season-high 15 points, and had five assists, as Vermont (11-3, 6-0 America East) grabbed sole possession of first place in the America East. The win was the Catamounts eighth-straight overall and their seventh consecutive at home. They also handed Boston U. (11-4, 5-1) its first loss in conference play and stopped the Terriers four-game win streak. "Absolutely, this is a great win for us," said Vermont coach Tom Brennan who recorded his 250th win at the school. "BU is a great team and I have so much respect for Dennis (Wolff) who is a great coach. "We had great success with threes, which was a big key since they are so good defending them," said Brennan. Vermont hit a season-best 52 percent from three-point range, converting a season-high 13 (in 25 attempts) against a stingy Terriers defense that had allowed 14 previous opponents to just 25 percent from beyond the arc. The Catamounts hit six in the first half en route to a 37-23 lead at the break. They used the three-pointer several times in the second half to counter BU runs that three times cut the margin to six points. David Hehn also chipped in with a season-high 11 points, nine in the second half, to pick up for Coppenrath, the nation's leading scorer heading into the game, who went six-for-16 from the floor. Boston University was led by Rashad Bell with 16 points and Chaz Carr who had 14. Kevin Gardner added eight points and seven boards.
